title: So Funny Story
summary: This is just a little about my saga of trying to get "Lucky's Stars" in front of the eyeballs of Star Citizen players around the world - well, at least those who read English, for now.
body:
I wrote this book (and I'm writing the trilogy) primarily for Star Citizen fans. In fact, a friend who is a published sci-fi writer who knows the "industry" pretty well advised me not to use the intellectual property around Star Citizen. He said it would keep more options open and maybe reach a wider audience without the SC elements. And I considered that. In fact, I was worried that since no other novels set in the world of SC were available, CIG would not give me permission to publish it - they're legal department was very opaque; they were not into having a chat about the project at all. It felt like the chances that CIG would approve the book for sale were low, but I decided to give it a go. I also started coming up with all the words/things I'd need to change to remove all references to Star Citizen. I have a list still.

But I really wanted to make the book for "the community." So I submitted it to CIG, through their process, and lo and behold they approved it promptly! Great, right?

Here's the "funny" part: now how to get it in the hands of SC players? I tried Facebook advertising, narrowly focused on the demographic for SC players. I tried paying for promotion on Amazon. And while I got a couple hundred "followers" on my Tripp Robbins Writing Facebook page, I don't think most of them are interested in the book, to be honest. So I asked myself where to find more SC players. Answer: Reddit! Spectrum (CIG's forums for the community). Sounds lke a natural, right?

Nope. I posted about the "first novel set in the world of Star Citizen approve by CIG for sale is now on Amazon" in Reddit, and in a half hour, I had a bunch of enthusiastic responss (and some book sales). But by 45 minutes, the post was taken down. The original message I got said it violated the r/starcitizen policies because it used AI. Well, I had included in the post an image I generated with Adobe Firefly that was definitely made with AI. So I took the image out and reposted the message (I think I even rewrote it). And like 20 minutes later I got a message saying I was now banned from the subReddit for repeatedly violating their policy!

What?? How?? Now I know a lot of people hate forum admins. But I've been a forum admin (in the 90s on AOL!), and I know it's hard. So I politely wrote back and said, "what do you mean? There's no AI in that post?" So I went around and around a bit, and I think it was the next day, I got a message saying they had reconsidered the ban and lifted it, but I couldn't promote a commercial book...OR ELSE. I sighed and said OK. -My friend Salty (the real one on whom the character is based) looked at the r/starcitizen policies and said, "It doesn't say anthing about not promoting things for sale!" And looking at their rules today, I still don't see anything about not promoting commercial products.

But wait, there's more! Last fall, I found a post on the subReddit about a novella that someone published with CIG's permission - and that post is still there! Link to original post

And to top that off, CIG took down my post on Spectrum telling the community about "Lucky's Stars" too!

I'm going to write to the r/starcitizen mods and see if they'll consider letting me post now, since the novella post is still there. Stay tuned.

title: Website Update
body: With a little help (OK, actually a lot of help) (Hmm, now I sound like SecUnit...) from Google Antigravity, I have reworked my website to be spiffier and, well, better. I'm also using GitHub Pages to host it. I have added this section, where I'll post occasional thoughts or updates. If you find any problems let me know!

title: LET'S TALK ABOUT MURDERBOT
summary: I am reading the Murderbot Diaries series and loving it. My editor on "Lucky's Stars" suggested them because of the first-person narration in both books, and she was so right.
body:
Readers are probably familiar with Martha Wells' Murderbot Diaries (a series with some offshoot stories) already. I think I was late to the party. But I've read everything that's out, and I'm looking forward to the May, 2026 release of the next book. The way Wells gets into the head of a "construct" - a mostly synthetic-but-slightly-organic "security unit" - is awesome. I think she has talked about ((Interview)) how the SecUnit seems kind of like some neurodivergent humans. She talked a little about that in the New Scientist interview. I relate to that sometimes, even if I'm fairly neurotypical.

I was also glad to hear Wells talk about how she develops her characters and stories. She sounds much more like a "pantser" than a "plotter." And I wrote "Lucky's Stars" as a confirmed pantser - putting the characters in a situation and then letting the story spin out of my head. I think that's great, but for my second book, I'm doing much more plotting, and I think the book will be better for that.
